positive.review: Absolutely fantastic game. Addictive core gameplay, excellent presentation, no crap. Lots of really fun / creative ways to approach the levels and interesting extra challenges for medals.

Absolutely in love with this after playing Shadow Tactics. All the way through mid-game it's still surprising you with new challenges, mechanics and characters that feel so fresh and exciting to play around with. Too bad the devs went bankrupt, I could've kept playing their games for the next 30yrs.

Really enjoyed this game!! It’s an outstanding experience from start to finish. Desperados III stands out as a meticulously crafted tactical stealth title, with the developers’ attention to detail and creativity evident in nearly every element.
Its flexible difficulty settings let players shape the adventure to their preferred pace and challenge level. Even the lowest setting still offers meaningful tension and thoughtful gameplay, and the optional badges and Baron Challenges provide a strong incentive to dive back in; encouraging new tactics and alternative routes through each map. The playable cast is varied and memorable, both mechanically and narratively, making it easy to get attached to them.... The plot is simple in the best way; feeling like a heartfelt nod to classic Western stories… and is complemented by excellent cutscenes.

A genuine standout in its genre.

This is essentially a puzzle game, so don't expect any action-heavy gun fights in this game. If you played the first Desperados (or similar games), or any other games from the dev, then this game is very similar.

However, for a puzzle game this is really well done and I finished the main story on hard mode in about 25 hours of gameplay. I haven't really looked into all the bonus content yet, which seems to be redoing missions with different enemies/setup.

Good:

* Completely bug-free experience from start to finish.

* No MTX or similar crap. There is an DLC which I haven't played.

* For an RTT game, the characters are very memorable.

* Doesn't try too hard to be nostalgic, and actually improves a lot over the old game's mechanics.

* Nearly all missions have an unique gimmick and style, and they are all enjoyable.

* The learning curve is flat enough that I didn't feel overwhelmed as someone who played the old game.

* The graphics are not too fancy, but the unique level designs make up for that.

* On hard mode, all the puzzles felt like they had the right difficulty. I never got stuck in hard mode, and I didn't struggle with ammo (which seems to be the main thing they reduced in hard mode).

Neutral:

* The story is low-stakes and not too exciting. But it still is enjoyable enough that doesn't distract from the gameplay.

* While there is a lot of potential to cheese missions (which is good), there are a few situations where it felt like there is only one 'valid' solution that you had to guess.

Bad:

* Unless I'm missed it, but the "action scheduling" (where you queue up actions) could have been made a bit nicer by adding some kind of timing functionality. Without this, you sometimes have to manually add timings by moving characters around or manually trigger the actions of each character.
Best start on beginner for fun, then make it a challenge.

The game is good if you like cowboys and turn-based tactics, but the shadow tactics are better. 
The only advantages are the game genre and the storyline, but the rest is not appealing.

Desperados 3 is an exceptionally well-made strategic stealth game, and the time and creativity invested by the developers shine through in every aspect.

Its range of difficulty levels lets players tailor the experience to their own pace, time, and tolerance for challenge. Even on Easy, the game provides a satisfying and meaningful level of difficulty, while the badges and Baron Challenges offer plenty of post-campaign motivation—encouraging fresh approaches to familiar mission grounds. The cast of characters is diverse, both in abilities and personality, making it easy for players to connect with them.

The storyline is straightforward—almost a loving tribute to classic Westerns—and is supported by well-crafted cinematics. 

A true gem.

A stealth masterpiece, balanced for any difficulty, it's a game where calm and patience prevail, and the mind is the key. Each map has different paths you can take, and you can vary your route. Each character uses different abilities, and you need to study them all to use them best. It's never boring, and I recommend saving often. The story is good, and it helps make the game better. I recommend watching some gameplay to understand the game a little. Rating: 10/10

Let me start this off by saying that if you aren't into trial and error stealth game-play this game is probably not for you. I also cannot speak for fans of the previous games, as I have not played any other The Desperados games. But as far as I know this is a prequel, so you can play it without touching the rest of the series if you choose. 

I am not usually into strategy games of a similar nature. I'm usually filtered out from the genre because it doesn't gel well with me. But after picking this one up again I feel like I owe it some credit just for how much content it has. Every level feels like a puzzle, and each character plays their specific role in solving parts of it. While the game can take some getting used to, everything will eventually begin to click. You'll start noticing how to utilize your characters more often or testing new routes and possibilities. It does a great job at teaching you each character's strengths and how use their abilities to your advantage while never feeling like it's holding your hand. Everything in this game was good to me, the banter between characters, the story, the lively beautiful maps, the cut scenes, the music, and the sound design. Everything it does it does well. I have almost no issues with this game other than the abrupt ending but that's about it. I love this game. 

Sadly Mimimi games shut down 2 years ago as of writing this review, being shut down less than a month after their final release Shadow Gambit: The Cursed Crew. So we're probably not going to be seeing another game like this for a long while. 

Fly High Mimimi

Geeze, I was halfway through this game when I learned that Mimimi Games have folded, which is disappointing, especially after seeing the love and effort they put into this in Desperados 3. The game starts slowly but becomes much harder as you progress. While I enjoy RT stealth tactics, I haven’t really played many since Commandos back in the day, and I found Normal difficulty a real slog after the first 6-7 missions or so, and switched to Beginner, which was still tough (or perhaps I suck at these games now). The gameplay improves over time, with deep tactical options that you can synchronise with crew’s unique skillsets to perform creative kills. My favourite was the Voodoo Queen.

Overall, it’s an excellent game with strong replay value due to its tactical options, challenges and diverse missions (there's even a bounty hunter mode, which adds new challenges to existing missions). The graphics were really impressive, but the story and dialogue are average.

[b]Rating: 10/10[/b]

I thought I was walking into a CRPG. What I actually got was a top-down [b]Assassin’s Creed[/b]. And honestly, it’s one of the best surprises I’ve ever had in a while.

[b]Desperados III[/b] is pure brilliance. Sixteen big, gorgeous levels, each one a puzzle box where you sneak, stab, set traps, and improvise your way through. The campaign took me over 40+ hours and I loved every second. The soundtrack feels straight out of a Hollywood's wild west, and the gameplay is pure perfection.

What makes it shine is it's freedom. No handholding, no 20-minute cutscenes teaching you how to click a mouse or press [b]F[/b] to pay respect. The game just drops you in and says, “here’s the tools, cowboy, figure it out.” I spent 2 hours staring at patrol routes, 15 minutes pulling off the perfect plan. And when that plan actually works, the satisfaction is unreal.

The crew is fantastic too. Hector bulldozes through enemies, Kate plays the trickster, and everyone has their own quirks that force you to mix and match strategies.

It’s a shame Mimimi Games shut down, but they went out on a high note. [b]Desperados III[/b] isn’t just a game, it’s the Wild West playground we didn’t know we needed.

Farewell Mimimi, and thanks for the memories.

When it comes to pure western-themed games, if you think about it, the choice is not very vast. Besides the obvious Red Dead Redemption series, I can only recall the Call of Juarez and GUN games from 15-20 years ago. For the rest, the western element is mostly contaminated with other elements, usually fantasy and/or post-apocalytptic themes (Evil West, Weird West, and Remnant come to my mind). So, to me, realizing that a modern era Desperados game had been done was quite the joy, but was it good? In short, yes.
Mechanically, the game is a jewel. The five playable characters complement each other well and the missions' level design is immaculate, offering countless different solutions to the same problem. The quicksaving system makes the game accessible and allows the players to either advance step by step or simply push and rush to get to the goal without having to deal with akward checkpoints.
Challenges and badges expand the playing time (which is already more than enough with the main campaign) without making it a chore, forcing you to think outside of the box to complete them.
Story-wise, the game is as cliché as a western can get, with all the pros and cons of it, so do not expect any sort of great writing nor a good story-pacing. You'll have to make the best of the characters personalities, which thankfully can count on a pretty good english dub and overall acting. They'll make for a good gang to be the mastermind of.
Technically, the game shows that it has been done by competent people. Ok, the maps do not make you drool in awe and the character models could have used a little more polishing, but it's a pleasing game to look at.
It's a shame that this genre is not as lively as it was 20 years ago. Besides the very few titans of the genre, not a single brand seems to be able to stay afloat. And considering that the dev team got disbanded, we can expect this to be the last Desperados game. But trust me when I say that if this game got released 20 years ago, today it would be considered a timeless classic. Nowadays, the consideration for this type of games cannot get that far, but even if this jem is destined to fall into oblivion, do yourself a favor and play it.

Great game focused around stealth and clever use of your characters abilities to distract, lure, kill and hide the bodies of your enemies as you move through each level towards your objective.

It has a very satisfying gameplay chain of identifying which guard is the weak link and can be picked off without notice. Then finding what guard is the new weak link after removing that last set of eyes. And slowly picking off enemies one at a time as you create new blind spots in the enemies patrol coverage until you've cleared an entire area of guards and can move about freely to your next area of guards and start the process again.

If you're after an action game about shoot outs then this isnt the game for you. Guns are generally a last resort due to the noise they make and need to be used sparingly for kill shots and only in very specific situations to avoid alerting the whole map. Most of the time if an enemy spots and start shooting at you its normally time to reload the last save rather than trying to shoot your way out of trouble.

This is more of a stealth puzzle game. That is extremely satisfying when your hard work and problem solving results in a map empty of enemies.

Well, it's good. Although if you are familiar with (and fond of) the original Desperados, a few of the changes might surprise or even annoy you at first. Desperados III, I assume in an effort to make itself harder to cheese, just kind of enjoys restricting the player. Characters are removed from your party in almost every mission, certain enemy types are immune to most of your abilities, and guns have been nerfed to now have annoyingly long cooldown after every shot. A few classic characters are also missing completely from the game.

But, I guess those are just petty, old man grievances. Desperados III is definitely a well-made and polished game that offers a good challenge, with plenty of huge missions in the main campaign, and even a good amount of additional side missions that you unlock along the way. It also looks and sounds great. Environments are vast, diverse and beautiful, the writing is decent (even if the main villain is extremely whatever), and the voice acting is good. I overall prefer the original, but this one's still solid, even if it annoyed me a bunch of times.

Real time stealth is not a genre I've been particularly drawn to in the past, but this game was a pleasant surprise. Between the immense amount of polish, quality UI, thoughtful level design, OST and sound design, VFX (shoutout to whoever made the bullet trail VFX. Clean as hell.) characters and their personalities, the banter and the story, it's definitely a game worth at least a try. Shame that the studio shut down. 8.5/10

作为新手没敢选最高难度，但还是在那疯狂SL，感觉叫它俯视角动作解谜游戏感觉更贴切。
顺便悼念一下mimimi.

Usually I wait until I completely finished a game before writing a review, but seriously, from the first couple of hours I already knew this is gonna be one of my favourite games. Strategic, precise, and cowboys?? This game basically ticked every box of mine, and you'll have to really try it to experience the kind of satisfaction of pulling off the perfect assassination plan.

*not really spoiler territory: There's a challenge in one of the earlier missions where you have to kill 3 targets at the same time. You're literally orchestrating an entire plan scripted in your mind, getting the timing exactly right down to the most minute detail. That was one of the best moments I've had in gaming.

★★★★★ out of 5

negative.review: Pretty boring unless you're into this specific type of game.

So the game is not bad in general, I just didn't like it. I like the genre and I played many games over the years similar from Desperados to Commandos. This game starts well and it is entertaining but at some point they introduced a magic user character which completely destroyed immersion. The in-game achievement are straight up unattainable and stupid sometimes. Earning those medals are over the top. Each segment is an our for me I take my time and sneak when I can. I like to use common sense tactics but the game is punishing that sometimes. I see when the game directly goes against my play style. Overall I didn't like the game but for the super cheap sub 10 euro I spent on it it was an okay title. Will not finish and definitely not 100%

Sick of reviews claiming a game is some generational masterpiece when it feels like an RTS mod from 20 years ago. Literally the most mid game you will play for a day or two and never touch again. This isnt a game that you have to love or hate, it is one that gets forgotten.
Not for me. gameplay is solid. game mechanics are solid. but the puzzle aspects are just too linear for me to look past.
Way too hard after the first set of missions- my hours played shows longer than I actually played, left the game open all night

I like the concept, and the gameplay. It was too difficult for me. I was on the 5th mission, and I couldn't figure out how to avoid all the guards in order to slay them silently, and once they were aware of me, they did so much damage that I'd die too quickly to gun them all down.

While I enjoyed parts of the game, overall I have to give this a negative review.  On the easiest setting it is WAY TOO DIFFICULT.  I literally had to save and reload some levels over 100 times before beating them.  The reason?  Every time you try something, a guard notices you.  Then you try to eliminate that guard and another guard notices you.  This repeats until you eliminate the one guard no one is watching, then work your way backwards.  The game should be called 'Who's looking at who?'  As a result the gameplay is far more restrictive than I had assumed.  All the saving and reloading, slowly picking away at each section becomes rather tedious.
  Also when I have to replay the same parts so many times, the music becomes repetitive and annoying.  There's a bug where every time you launch the game it ignores the music setting and has to be reset.  The music is good but not when I have to listen to the same thing over and over.
  While I love westerns, I would not buy Desperados IV, which won't be a problem since the studio that made these games closed shop.  *Whew*
